author: By Aaron Boxerman, Iyad Abuheweila, Hiba Yazbek and Michael Levenson
title: Netanyahu Orders Evacuation Plan for City Where a Million Gazans Shelter
description: Many civilians in Rafah are sheltering in rickety tents made of plastic and wood and say there is nowhere left in Gaza to avoid Israeli shelling.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has ordered the Israeli military to draw up plans to evacuate Rafah, a Gazan city packed with more than a million people, in advance of an expected ground offensive that has set off international alarm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Joao Silva
title: China Keeps Building Stadiums in Africa. But at What Cost?
description: This year’s Africa Cup of Nations, like several previous editions, played out in Chinese-built arenas. It will end with familiar questions about their legacy.
content: The Alassane Ouattara stadium rises like a piece of sculpture from the dusty brown earth north of Ivory Coast’s largest city, its undulating roof and white columns towering over the empty landscape like a spaceship that has dropped onto a uninhabited planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella, Guy Barak, David Blumenfeld, Alexandra Eaton and Emily Rhyne
title: These Israelis and Palestinians Are Still Working for Peace. Just Quietly.
description: Positions have hardened on both sides in the face of the Gaza war, but some activists refuse to give up hope. They let us sit in on one of their meetings.
content: On a sunny January day, dozens of Israelis and Palestinians crowded into a small house in a town outside Bethlehem, as their compatriots fought in the Gaza Strip, to talk about a subject that has become nearly taboo in their cities and towns:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: On a Frozen Border, Finland Puzzles Over a ‘Russian Game’
description: As it votes on Sunday for a new president, NATO’s newest member says Moscow is testing it by turning asylum seekers into a political pressure point.
content: Poking up through the snow drifts on the Finnish-Russian border lies a symbol of Moscow’s biggest provocation yet toward NATO’s newest member: a sprawling heap of broken bicycles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: New N.Y. Law Mandates More Transparency in Credit Card Surcharges
description: The state law, which goes into effect Sunday, requires businesses to include any surcharges in the prices listed for the products or services they sell.
content: A new law going into effect on Sunday will require businesses in New York to clearly post the cost of purchasing items with a credit card, including any surcharges being imposed, for customers before checkout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Why the Age Issue Is Hurting Biden So Much More Than Trump
description: Both Donald J. Trump and President Biden are over 75. But voters are much less likely to worry that Mr. Trump is too old to serve.
content: Donald J. Trump has praised Hungary’s prime minister, Viktor Orban, for his leadership of Turkey, and confused Nikki Haley and Nancy Pelosi. President Biden has named dead former European leaders when describing his contemporary peers, and referred to Egypt as Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Boxes, Tape, $10,000: What It Takes to Move Into an N.Y.C. Apartment
description: Upfront costs for renters — security deposits, broker fees and a month’s rent — are at their highest levels in years, another sign of the city’s housing crisis.
content: Hannah Brooks needed a new apartment and she was running out of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: Why Is Everything Suddenly Taylor Swift’s Fault?
description: At last, one thing that all Americans can agree on.
content: Ask the people in your life to name a woman who’s got it good, with wealth and beauty and talent and true love, and I’d bet at least a few of them would name Taylor Swift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: What Do Beyoncé, ‘Dynasty,’ and Halle Berry Have in Common? His Clothes.
description: He has dressed music, TV and Hollywood stars. He has had a fashion business since the 1980s. His clothes have become social media hits. But B Michael is not a household name.
content: He has had a fashion business in New York since the late 1980s, the same decade that Michael Kors and Donna Karan started their namesake lines. He was inducted into the Council of Fashion Designers of America in 1998. From 1999 to 2018, he showed two collections each year, some on the schedule at New York Fashion Week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Winter Storm Could Bring Up to a Foot of Snow to Parts of the Northeast
description: The heaviest snow is expected in parts of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and southern New England starting on Monday into Tuesday, forecasters said.
content: A winter storm is expected to move through the Northeast starting on Monday and lasting into Tuesday, bringing up to a foot of snow in some areas stretching from central Pennsylvania to the Catskills and Hudson Valley in New York, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: The First Meaning of ‘Crush’ Came Long Before a ‘First Crush’
description: Cupid is no lexicographer. So, before Valentine’s Day, we looked into the evolution of the word “crush.”
content: A crush can be thrilling, said Anna Martin, the host of the New York Times podcast “Modern Love.” It can also be devastating or just “a starting point” — if not of a romantic relationship then of self-discovery. “In every story we’ve had about a crush, someone learned something about themselves from having it,” Ms. Martin told Times Insider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Bensinger and Kellen Browning
title: Once an Escape, Sports Talk Embraces Politics
description: Come for the draft analysis, stay for the anti-Biden rant. A growing class of commentators is blending sports and conservative politics.
content: Just before flying to Las Vegas this week for the Super Bowl, Clay Travis announced his prediction for the game on his popular sports podcast, “OutKick.” The San Francisco 49ers would defeat the Kansas City Chiefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: No More Legal Games for Donald Trump
description: The Supreme Court can put a stop to the former president’s attempts to delay his criminal trial.
content: The most important words to issue from the federal appeals court in Washington on Tuesday were not in its unanimous 57-page opinion rejecting Donald Trump’s claim of absolute immunity from prosecution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Shocking Opposition Victory Throws Pakistan Into Chaos
description: The party of Imran Khan, the jailed former prime minister, took the most seats, humiliating the country’s military rulers and creating a political crisis.
content: The party of the imprisoned former prime minister of Pakistan, Imran Khan, won the most seats in parliamentary elections this week, delivering a strong rebuke to the country’s powerful generals and throwing the political system into chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Bright Ideas
description: Peter Koetters makes a glowing Sunday debut puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Lisa Lerer
title: Inside Biden’s Protective White House
description: The White House’s cloistered nature reflects the concern of aides who worry that even small mistakes will be amplified. Lately, the president has burst through that bubble, with mixed results.
content: Aides have President Biden take the shorter stairs to board Air Force One. When it comes to news conferences, they yell loudly — and quickly — to end the questions, sometimes stealing a classic awards show tactic and playing loud music to signal the conclusion of the event. And forget about regular interviews with major news publications, including a traditional presidential sit-down on Super Bowl Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Schwarzbaum
title: A New Biography Tackles the Remarkable Career of Stanley Kubrick
description: On the 25th anniversary of the director’s death, two film scholars have published “Kubrick: An Odyssey.”
content: The passions, obsessions, habits, talents and fears that shaped the extraordinary movies of Stanley Kubrick were well chewed over in his lifetime. Some of the reporting came from those who knew him; other impressions came from journalists who didn’t know him, but enjoyed the digging. It was easy quarrying, because there was so much rich topsoil. A son of the Bronx who became the self-styled squire of Childwickbury Manor in Hertfordshire, England, Kubrick was a visionary filmmaker whose greatest works — including “Paths of Glory” and “Dr. Strangelove,” “Lolita” and “2001: A Space Odyssey,” “The Shining” and “A Clockwork Orange” — are as vital and prescient about culture and society today as they were when they blazed through the second half of the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Books From Down Under
description: Scrappy domestic novellas and a novel about the unhappy rich.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Egypt Warily Eyes Gaza as War Builds Pressure on Its Border
description: Egypt has reinforced its frontier with Gaza and warned Israel that any move that would send Gazans spilling into Egyptian territory could jeopardize their decades-old peace treaty.
content: The pressure on Egypt is building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg and Jillian Weinberger
title: Don’t Underestimate the Mobilizing Force of Abortion
description: Poland voted out authoritarianism. Reproductive rights tipped the scales.
content: Poland recently ousted its right-wing, nationalist Law and Justice Party. In 2020, a party-appointed tribunal severely restricted the country’s abortion rights, sparking nationwide protests and an opposition movement. After a trip to Poland, the Times Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg came to recognize that similar dynamics could prevail in the United States in 2024. In this audio essay, she argues that Joe Biden’s campaign should take note of what a “powerful mobilizing force the backlash to abortion bans can be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Math or Magic?
description: Two schools of thought on the best way to find love.
content: When it comes to finding love, there seem to be two schools of thought on the best way to go about it. One says, wait for that lightning-strike magic. The other says, make a calculation and choose the best option. Which school has it right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: Our Condo Building Has a Huge Roof. Why Aren’t More People Allowed on It?
description: It’s possible that the listed limits in a building’s offering plans are lower than what city code allows. Here’s how to find out.
content: Q: We have two rooftop lounges on top of our Hell’s Kitchen condominium building, where I serve on the board. Residents use them and sometimes rent them for private events. There are maximum capacities for the lounges listed in the building’s offering plans, but they seem too low — the spaces have double doors and double exits for easy evacuation in case of emergency. We were never told to post capacity limits for the residents, as public places are. How do we find out how many people can legally be in these lounges at the same time?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Ye’s New LP Debuts at a New York Arena. Why Do His Fans Stay Loyal?
description: The rapper formerly known as Kanye West has been mired in controversy after making a string of antisemitic remarks. Thousands showed up to hear “Vultures 1” on Friday night.
content: Adidas severed ties with him. His talent agency dropped him. But on Friday night, an arena on Long Island was filled with thousands of people who most certainly had not turned their backs on Ye, the artist formerly known as Kanye West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: A War-Haunted Choreographer Steps Into a New Role at City Ballet
description: Alexei Ratmansky, arguably the most important ballet choreographer today, has made a deeply personal first work as artist in residence that reflects his Ukrainian roots.
content: For the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, the last two years have brought an uncomfortable intermingling of life and art. Known for ballets that combine wit with an almost surrealistic imagination, he has found his thoughts drawn insistently toward the war in Ukraine, the country where he spent his early years and began his dancing career, where he met his wife and where their families still live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senators Work Into Weekend on Ukraine and Israel Bill as G.O.P. Slows Progress
description: The $95 billion package appeared on track for eventual passage, but Republicans who killed a bipartisan version were still trying to make changes.
content: The long-stalled emergency national security package to send aid to Ukraine and Israel is back on track in the Senate and headed toward passage within days — but not before Republican senators try to take a few partisan shots at the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Bones on Canadian Beach Are Likely From a Shipwreck, but Which One?
description: Human remains found last month in an area of Prince Edward Island that was perilous for ships were most likely buried after a shipwreck in the 1800s, experts say.
content: Human bones were found protruding from the side of an eroding cliff on Prince Edward Island in Canada late last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts and Lola Fadulu
title: Six Dead After Helicopter Crashes in California, Officials Say
description: The crash happened on Friday night in California near the Nevada border, roughly 60 miles south of Las Vegas, the authorities said.
content: A helicopter carrying six people crashed and caught on fire on Friday night near the California-Nevada border, killing all of those aboard, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: Brazil Has a Dengue Emergency, Portending a Health Crisis for the Americas
description: Record numbers of cases of the mosquito-borne virus have been reported in the Southern Hemisphere summer, and the surge is likely to move north.
content: Brazil is experiencing an enormous outbreak of dengue fever, the sometimes fatal mosquito-borne disease, and public health experts say it is a harbinger of a coming surge in cases in the Americas, including Puerto Rico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: A ‘Mother’ Is Mourned by the Queer New Yorkers She Left Behind
description: Hundreds gathered in a Greenwich Village church to pay their respects to the transgender activist Cecilia Gentili, who died this week at 52.
content: The strumming of a Spanish guitar and the voices of Eydie Gormé and Los Panchos echoed throughout the hall as “Sabor a Mí” played on a loudspeaker. Hundreds of mourners made their way into Judson Memorial Church, near Washington Square Park in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oleksandr Chubko, Carlotta Gall and Lynsey Addario
title: Russian Drone Strike Ignites a Fuel Depot, Setting a Neighborhood Ablaze in Ukraine
description: Seven people from two families died in the inferno in Kharkiv on Friday night, as burning oil flowed like lava. “People were doomed,” an official said.
content: Firefighters were digging through the burned remains of a house Saturday morning searching for the body of a child, the last member of a family killed in a catastrophic fire caused by a Russian drone attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Raicovich and Laura Hanna
title: To Save Museums, Treat Them Like Highways
description: Midsize cultural venues are teetering on the brink. To save them, we need to fund them like other forms of essential infrastructure.
content: Ask any workers in the nonprofit arts sector — maybe after they have had a few drinks — and they will tell you that arts funding in this country is a mess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: For Some Couples, Marrying on Super Bowl Weekend Is a Win
description: First comes wedding cake. Then game-day margaritas.
content: In weddings, as in football, the will to win may be nothing without the will to prepare. That’s why Laura Arvizu and Robert Marquez, of Paso Robles, Calif., started planning their wedding in Mexico 14 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 10, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 10, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about a growing number of schools extending the deadline for registration commitments because of delayed financial aid information, using incorrect information provided by Saint Louis University, misstated Rob Reddy’s title at Saint Louis University. He is interim vice president of enrollment management, not vice president of enrollment management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Julie Bosman, Audra D. S. Burch and Jenna Russell
title: Other 80-Somethings Have Thoughts About Age and the Presidency
description: President Biden’s age has once again become a talking point in national politics. Many older Americans agree that it’s an issue; others feel it’s insulting.
content: Bill Murphy, an 80-year-old retired veterinarian in suburban Phoenix, sometimes blanks on names he could once summon with ease, so he has empathy for 81-year-old President Biden. But he winced when he watched Mr. Biden defend his mental sharpness at a news conference, only to mix up the presidents of Egypt and Mexico. Mr. Murphy, a Republican, believes Mr. Biden is not up to another term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Founding Father of a New American Style
description: Willy Chavarria makes the case for a new (multi)national style.
content: The sun had gone down on the first day of New York Fashion Week — which also happened to be the first day of the whole fashion season — when Willy Chavarria invited everyone to a drive-in on the far reaches of Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Rocked, So to Speak
description: Zhouqin Burnikel returns to the Saturday puzzle page in style.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Although this is Zhouqin Burnikel’s 79th New York Times crossword, it has been more than six long years since we’ve solved a Saturday grid by her. She is a constructor with a devoted following; many solvers who started in the last decade grew to love her wit and subtle style in themed puzzles on Mondays and Tuesdays. She shines just as brightly in a challenging grid like this one, which is technically themeless, although it does feature a particular celebratory event that we discover as we solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: Fragments of Asteroid With Mystery Origin Are Found Outside Berlin
description: Astronomers tracked the entry of a small space rock into Earth’s atmosphere, and then meteorite hunters made an unexpected discovery.
content: Scientists have found pieces of a meteorite that fell near Berlin just after midnight on Jan. 21. It is a rare find, from an asteroid that was identified just before it entered Earth’s atmosphere. Only a handful of such events in the recent past have allowed astronomers to trace an incoming rock’s origin in the solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Backpack You Need Isn’t for Carrying Books
description: Study Spanish in Bolivia. Or teach English in South Korea. Or volunteer in Nepal.
content: Why has the isolationist wing of Congress been blocking aid to Ukraine and become, in effect, a tool for President Vladimir Putin of Russia?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amity Gaige
title: A Tale of Midlife Love With a Bombshell Ending
description: In her new novel, “Leaving,” Roxana Robinson reunites a former couple. One of them is divorced; the other is still married. What now?
content: Every love story needs an obstacle, someone or something that threatens to keep the lovers apart. What obstacles are suitable for a contemporary American love story? The writer of such a story may wish to avoid the over-communication, the tolerance (real or performed) and the jadedness that dispel romantic tension. Can lovers still be “star-crossed,” doomed from the start to labor under a “malign star”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Kicak
title: My First Cigarette Was My Last
description: Thoughts on the coolest boy in Ontario.
content: Our elementary school was set deep in the rural Ontario countryside, nestled in the forest beside the local dump. In the late 1990s, when I was in sixth grade, the school had a drug bust in which more than 20 kids were suspended and charged with possession of marijuana, magic mushrooms and ecstasy. I was not one of those kids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Hungary’s President Resigns Amid Outcry Over Sex Abuse Case Pardon
description: Katalin Novak, an outspoken champion of family values, announced her resignation on Saturday, the latest in a series of prominent figures in the governing party felled by sex scandals.
content: The president of Hungary, a loyal and largely powerless ally of the country’s authoritarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, resigned on Saturday amid a public outcry over her pardoning of a man implicated in a sex abuse scandal at a children’s home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Mahomes Says He’s ‘Not Even Close’ to Brady
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 10, 2024.
content: “He will throw it to anybody, anywhere, at any time. And it will be on the money.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Memory Loss Requires Careful Diagnosis, Scientists Say
description: A federal investigator said that President Biden had “poor memory” and “diminished faculties.” But such a diagnosis would require close medical assessment, experts said.
content: A lengthy report by the Department of Justice on President Biden’s handling of classified documents contained some astonishing assessments of his well-being and mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Debate Over Transgender Care and Detransitioning
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about children with gender dysphoria who regret their transitions.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Emma Goldberg
title: He Grew Up in the Shadow of the ‘Wolf of Wall Street.’ Then He Got Into Debt Settlement.
description: Ryan Sasson built a business that reaped hundreds of millions of dollars in fees for helping people negotiate down their debts. But former clients — and prosecutors — say it was exploitative.
content: In the early 1980s, 19-year-old Jordan Belfort — who would go on to become known as the Wolf of Wall Street, a title he bestowed on himself in a tell-all memoir — had a fortuitous encounter on Jones Beach, on Long Island, with another teenager selling ice cream named Stephen Drescher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Daisy Ridley Loves Every Single Track of This Stormzy Album
description: When the star of the film “Sometimes I Think About Dying” listens to “This Is What I Mean,” she says, “I don’t shuffle it, nothing. It’s perfect.”
content: For her latest movie, “Sometimes I Think About Dying,” Daisy Ridley plays Fran, a drab, standoffish, occasionally obnoxious office worker. Strangely enough, she found it exciting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: A Young Basketball Player and a Coach Found Each Other Just in Time
description: Arthur Dukes Jr. had made three false starts at college before becoming the star player for LaGuardia Community College’s scrappy new team.
content: Arthur Dukes Jr. played in pickup basketball games whenever he could, which is why he showed up for an open-gym session at Public School 92 in Harlem one evening last year. At 21, he was living at home in a two-bedroom apartment with his parents and seven siblings while working as a security guard at a shoe store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: U.N. Agency in Gaza Fought Hamas Infiltration; Not Hard Enough, Israel Says
description: The main U.N. agency in Gaza said it has long investigated claims of links, firing several employees over the years. Israel says it is a compromised organization too weak to protect itself.
content: When the United Nations launched an investigation a decade ago into whether a handful of its employees in Gaza were members of Hamas, it was not long before a senior U.N. legal officer in the territory started receiving death threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Trump Insinuates Haley’s Husband Deployed to Africa to Escape Her
description: At a rally in South Carolina on Saturday, former President Donald J. Trump asked of Nikki Haley: “What happened to her husband? Where is he?”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump continued his aggressive attacks on Nikki Haley Saturday, insinuating at a rally in South Carolina that her husband, a National Guardsmen, left for a deployment in order to escape her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: 6 Bodies Found at Burned Pennsylvania House Where 2 Officers Were Shot
description: The authorities said on Friday that they believed they had recovered the remains of six family members, including the person believed to have shot a young niece and two police officers.
content: The remains of six family members have been recovered from a burned home in southeastern Pennsylvania, including those of a man who is believed to have shot two police officers on Wednesday, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Moody’s Downgrades Israel’s Credit Rating, Citing Toll of War
description: Israel’s creditworthiness remains high, but the rating agency noted that the outlook for the country was negative considering the risks from the continued conflict.
content: Moody’s on Friday became the first major rating agency to downgrade Israel’s creditworthiness, citing the prolonged war with Hamas and the toll it is taking on the country’s finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: The Big Pregame (Vegas’s Version)
description: Super Bowl week is an excuse to party every year. In Las Vegas, events featuring Future, Travis Scott and Ice Spice are supersize.
content: Music blared as the Baltimore Ravens wide receiver Odell Beckham Jr. had a conversation across a barricade. Close by were Machine Gun Kelly, the platinum-blond musician, and his partner, the actor Megan Fox. Outside the 45,000-square-foot, strobe-light-filled tent near the Las Vegas Strip, a man climbed a life-size statue of an elephant. Other partyers cheered him on and snapped pictures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Cher, Mariah Carey and Sinead O’Connor Are Rock Hall Nominees
description: Oasis and Sade will appear on the ballot for the first time, alongside Dave Matthews Band, A Tribe Called Quest, Mary J. Blige and others.
content: Cher, Mariah Carey, Sinead O’Connor, Oasis and Sade are among the first-time nominees for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame’s class of 2024, which were revealed Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘True Detective’ Season 4, Episode 5 Recap: Dots Finally Connect
description: This week’s episode finally answers some questions that have been teased out for a long time.
content: This week’s recap is posting earlier than usual because the episode premiered Friday on Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Question Is Not If Biden Should Step Aside. It’s How.
description: Condense the nomination into the format that was originally designed for handling intraparty competition: the Democratic convention.
content: Joe Biden should not be running for re-election. That much was obvious well before the special prosecutor’s comments on the president’s memory lapses inspired a burst of age-related angst. And Democrats who are furious at the prosecutor have to sense that it will become only more obvious as we move deeper into an actual campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Love Letters
description: Valentine’s Day is on Wednesday. It’s the one day a year when we endorse unfettered demonstrations of affection, but it doesn’t need to to be.
content: It was customary when I was in grade school to bestow a valentine upon every person in one’s class. These valentines were not of the handmade or heartfelt variety, but rather bought in bulk from CVS, from the red-cellophane aisle, on the shelf next to the seasonal Whitman’s Samplers and conversation hearts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Weekend News Anchor Who Wakes Up Before Dawn Spends Her Sundays
description: Shannan Ferry, who co-anchors “Weekends on 1” for NY1, wakes up in the middle of the night to head to work, then spends her day on dates or with friends.
content: “I’m more of a morning than a night person,” Shannan Ferry said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leila Miller and Mary Triny Zea
title: Panamanian Candidate, Facing Prison, Vows to Campaign From an Embassy
description: Convicted of money laundering, Ricardo Martinelli, a conservative ex-president who had planned to run again, has sought refuge in the embassy of leftist and autocratic Nicaragua.
content: As Panama jumps into its boisterous Carnival period, the celebrations this weekend come amid a bizarre political drama playing out in the capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Kevin Draper, Michael J. de la Merced and Sarah Kessler
title: The New N.F.L. Owners?
description: As team valuations skyrocket, the league is weighing whether to relax ownership rules that prohibit investment from private equity funds.
content: The biggest upcoming football event for many of the N.F.L. owners and business executives who will populate luxury boxes at the Super Bowl this weekend is not, perhaps surprisingly, the game. It actually won’t take place until six weeks later, in Orlando, Fla., when football executives gather for the National Football League’s annual meeting — an event that has particular significance this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt and Francesca Paris
title: Is Taylor Swift Actually Increasing N.F.L. Ratings?
description: We looked into whether such a claim was merely a romantic notion.
content: Ever since Taylor Swift started dating the Kansas City Chiefs’ Travis Kelce, she has elevated him into a new tier of celebrity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: How Biden’s Mishandling of Classified Papers Differs From Trump’s Criminal Case
description: Two superficially similar special counsel investigations came to contrasting ends — criminal charges in one case, and closure in the other — because the facts significantly diverged.
content: A special counsel’s conclusion that “no criminal charges are warranted” against President Biden for possessing classified material while he was out of office stands in contrast with another special counsel’s decision to bring criminal charges against former President Donald J. Trump for keeping classified documents after he left the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and David E. Sanger
title: Biden and German Leader Meet at White House and Push for Ukraine Aid
description: The message came as congressional lawmakers were working on a package with billions in assistance but an uncertain fate.
content: President Biden and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany used a meeting at the Oval Office on Friday to pressure Congress to pass billions more in aid for Ukraine, as legislative dysfunction and opposition among some Republicans have left the critical package in limbo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Trump Co-Defendant Suggests Georgia Prosecutors Lied About Relationship Timing
description: A lawyer for the co-defendant said she had a witness who could testify that the relationship began before Fani Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, hired Nathan Wade.
content: A lawyer for one of former President Donald J. Trump’s co-defendants in the Georgia election case suggested on Friday that the two prosecutors leading the case had lied about when their romantic relationship started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: A Graphic Novel Finds a Relatable Hero in a Modern African Woman
description: The “Aya” series explores the pains and pleasures of everyday life in a working-class neighborhood in West Africa.
content: One of the most successful African comics has no super heroes, and certainly no supernatural powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada Prepares for Soccer’s 2026 World Cup
description: While no new stadiums will be built in Vancouver or Toronto, multimillion-dollar renovations must be finished on a tight deadline.
content: This week we learned how many World Cup games will take place in Vancouver and Toronto, which will co-host the men’s soccer tournament with cities in the United States and Mexico in 2026.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: For Gen Z, an Age-Old Question: Who Pays for Dates?
description: Young people tend to lean more liberal on a range of issues pertaining to relationship norms. But when it comes to dating, the idea that men should pay still prevails in heterosexual courtship.
content: During a recent dinner at a cozy bar in Upper Manhattan, I was confronted with an age-old question about gender norms. Over bowls of ramen and sips of gin cocktails, my date and I got into a debate: Who should pay for dates?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Andy Kim Wins a Vote Rich in Symbolism in Race to Replace Menendez
description: The third-term congressman won key Democratic support Saturday in his run for U.S. Senate in New Jersey, beating the state’s first lady, Tammy Murphy, on her home turf.
content: Representative Andy Kim, a third-term Democratic congressman, won an early but significant victory on Saturday against New Jersey’s first lady, Tammy Murphy, as they compete in one of the country’s most closely watched Senate primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: Two Pianists Make a Life Out of an Intimate Art Form
description: Pavel Kolesnikov and Samson Tsoy, partners onstage and off, began to play as a duo in school. Now, they are dedicating their careers to it.
content: It looked like some kind of grand music exam. The pianists Pavel Kolesnikov and Samson Tsoy sat down at their instruments onstage at Wigmore Hall and began to play for an audience of two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Super Snacks for the Super Bowl
description: Though we’d welcome baked Buffalo wings, bacon-Cheddar dip and Frito pie on any given Sunday.
content: New York Times Cooking isn’t known for its sports coverage — you’ll want to head over to The Athletic for that — but one thing we do know is snacks. We know crunchy snacks. We know melty snacks. We know savory snacks and sweet snacks and salty snacks and sour snacks and spicy snacks. So while we may struggle to explain the particulars of the Big Sports Game tomorrow, we certainly have the snacks quotient covered, and you should make Ali Slagle’s baked Buffalo wings. They’re easy, fast and a fan favorite: That classic mix of garlicky hot sauce and funky blue cheese is always a winner. We’d say to set out plenty of napkins, but let’s be real, everyone will be licking their fingers clean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Oklahoma Judge Resigns After Exchanging 500 Texts During Murder Trial
description: Traci Soderstrom, a district judge in Lincoln County, said that the messages sent while she was on the bench during the trial were “inappropriate.”
content: A judge in Oklahoma who exchanged 500 text messages with her bailiff while presiding over the murder trial of a man accused of beating a toddler to death resigned on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Glenn Thrush
title: Trump Calls His Classified Documents Case ‘Selective Persecution’
description: In a speech in Harrisburg, Pa., on Friday, former President Donald J. Trump said if President Biden was not going to be charged over classified documents, he should not be either.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who faces a criminal case accusing him of illegally retaining classified documents, blasted on Friday a special counsel’s decision not to charge President Biden for his handling of classified material, accusing prosecutors of an unfair double standard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: How Old Is Too Old to Be President? An Uncomfortable Question Arises Again.
description: Either of the leading 2024 candidates would be the oldest occupant of the Oval Office ever by the end of his term, and neither seems eager to discuss the ramifications.
content: When Dwight D. Eisenhower weighed the pros and cons of running for a second term, one factor that concerned him was his age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: Missing 6-Year-Old and Rescue Team Found Dead in Gaza, Aid Group Says
description: The Palestine Red Crescent had issued a series of posts about the girl, named Hind, and two rescuers sent to find her after she was trapped in a car with dead relatives in it.
content: A 6-year-old Palestinian girl and the two rescuers who went looking for her nearly two weeks ago were found dead on Saturday, the Palestine Red Crescent said, ending a desperate effort to discover their fates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock, Muktita Suhartono and Nyimas Laula
title: Manhattan or Pulau Rhun? In 1667, Nutmeg Made the Choice a No-Brainer.
description: Growing a spice once worth its weight in gold, a tiny isle in Indonesia was so coveted that the Dutch traded Manhattan for it. Some 350 years later, life on the two islands couldn’t be more different.
content: The isles of Manhattan and Pulau Rhun could hardly be farther apart, not just in geography, but also in culture, economy and global prominence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz and Sinna Nasseri
title: The Super Bowl in Las Vegas: What Would Hunter S. Thompson Think?
description: Thompson’s 1971 book “Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas” and a later article on the Super Bowl glimpsed much of what has become of these exemplars of American excess.
content: “When you bring an act into this town, you want to bring it in heavy. Don’t waste any time with cheap shucks and misdemeanors. Go straight for the jugular. Get right into felonies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marilyn Ong
title: How New Technology Changed Mahjong
description: Electronic tables, which can cost thousands of dollars, are fueling new interest in the game.
content: If you run through iconic mahjong scenes from film — classics like “The Joy Luck Club” or the final throwdown in “Crazy Rich Asians” — they all start with an almost ritualistic shuffling, the players’ hands sweeping the table, the tiles clacking in a happy clamor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Mr. President, Ditch the Stealth About Health
description: Biden must confront the age-old question.
content: Once, when my father was in West Virginia on police business, a man approached him and demanded to know about “rumors” that President Franklin Roosevelt was “crippled.” The man threatened to beat up my father or anyone who said F.D.R. was in a wheelchair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Peterson
title: At the Border, a Blending of Politics and Religion
description: A rally along the Rio Grande featured an unexpected blend of political anger and religious ardor.
content: Last Saturday, a crowd of several hundred people gathered in a grassy field near the bank of the Rio Grande in Quemado, Texas, for a rally in support of the state’s defiant stance on immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: 15-Year-Old Is Arrested in Shooting of a Tourist in Times Square
description: The teenager, Jesus Alejandro Rivas Figueroa, is accused of firing at a security guard and instead hitting a woman from Brazil.
content: A 15-year-old boy was arrested on Friday, accused of shooting a Brazilian tourist in Times Square the night before and then firing twice at a police officer while fleeing the scene, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: China Welcomes a Chilly Year of the Dragon
description: The Lunar New Year begins on Saturday. Here is how the holiday is going in China.
content: The Lunar New Year begins on Saturday. Here is how the holiday is going in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Lost Images Reveal the History of Rio’s Carnival
description: A pile of film negatives started a collector on an obsession to collect old photos that offer a history of  Rio de Janeiro and the event that has made it world famous — carnival.
content: A pile of film negatives started a collector on an obsession to collect old photos that offer a history of  Rio de Janeiro and the event that has made it world famous — carnival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Gazans Search Rubble After Israeli Strikes on Rafah
description: Homes and a vehicle were hit in the southern Gazan city where hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians have fled since the war began.
content: Homes and a vehicle were hit in the southern Gazan city where hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians have fled since the war began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Barak, David Blumenfeld, Adam Sella, Alexandra Eaton and Emily Rhyne
title: Promoting Peace as War Rages: Israeli and Palestinian Activists Meet
description: For almost 20 years, Combatants For Peace has called for non-violence and an “end to Israel’s occupation of Palestine.” But after Oct. 7, some attendees are more hesitant to speak out about their activism. Times reporters attended one of their sessions.
content: For almost 20 years, Combatants For Peace has called for non-violence and an “end to Israel’s occupation of Palestine.” But after Oct. 7, some attendees are more hesitant to speak out about their activism. Times reporters attended one of their sessions.
source.name: The New York Times
